#Text=41 : The Politics of Fear : How It Manipulates Us to Tribalism ( Javanbakht )
#Text=By Arash Javanbakht
#Text=President Barack Obama walks away from the lectern with Vice President Joe Biden after making a statement about the mass shooting in Orlando , Fla. , June 16 , 2016 .
#Text=( Official White House Photo by Pete Souza ) Public Domain

#Text=The cruel murder of 50 people in New Zealand was another tragic reminder of how humans are capable of heartlessly killing their own kind just based on what they believe , how they worship , and what race or nationality they belong to .
#Text=There is a longstanding history of the fear of “ the others ” turning humans into illogical ruthless weapons , in service to an ideology .
#Text=Fear is arguably as old as life .
#Text=It is deeply ingrained in the living organisms that have survived extinction through billions of years of evolution .
#Text=Its roots are deep in our core psychological and biological being , and it is one of our most intimate feelings .
#Text=Danger and war are as old as human history , and so are politics and religion .
#Text=Demagogues have always used fear for intimidation of the subordinates or enemies , and shepherding the tribe by the leaders .
#Text=Fear is a very strong tool that can blur humans ’ logic and change their behavior .
#Text=I am a psychiatrist and neuroscientist specializing in fear and trauma , and I have some evidence - based thoughts on how fear is abused in politics .
#Text=We learn fear from tribe mates
#Text=Like other animals , we humans can learn fear from experience , such as being attacked by a predator .
#Text=We also learn from observation , such as witnessing a predator attacking another human .
#Text=And , we learn by instructions , such as being told there is a predator nearby .
#Text=Learning from our conspecifics – members of the same species – is an evolutionary advantage that has prevented us from repeating dangerous experiences of other humans .
#Text=We have a tendency to trust our tribe mates and authorities , especially when it comes to danger .
#Text=It is adaptive : Parents and wise old men told us not to eat a special plant , or not to go to an area in the woods , or we would be hurt .
#Text=By trusting them , we would not die like a great - grandfather who died eating that plant .
#Text=This way we accumulated knowledge .
#Text=Tribalism has been an inherent part of the human history .
#Text=There has always been competition between groups of humans in different ways and with different faces , from brutal wartime nationalism to a strong loyalty to a football team .
#Text=Evidence from cultural neuroscience shows that our brains even respond differently at an unconscious level simply to the view of faces from other races or cultures .
#Text=At a tribal level , people are more emotional and consequently less logical : Fans of both teams pray for their team to win , hoping God will take sides in a game .
#Text=On the other hand , we regress to tribalism when afraid .
#Text=This is an evolutionary advantage that would lead to the group cohesion and help us fight the other tribes to survive .
#Text=Tribalism is the biological loophole that many politicians have banked on for a long time : tapping into our fears and tribal instincts .
#Text=Some examples are Nazism , the Ku Klux Klan , religious wars and the Dark Ages .
#Text=The typical pattern is to give the other humans a different label than us , and say they are going to harm us or our resources , and to turn the other group into a concept .
#Text=It does not have to necessarily be race or nationality , which are used very often .
#Text=It can be any real or imaginary difference : liberals , conservatives , Middle Easterners , white men , the right , the left , Muslims , Jews , Christians , Sikhs .
#Text=The list goes on and on .

#Text=When building tribal boundaries between “ us ” and “ them , ” some politicians have managed very well to create virtual groups of people that do not communicate and hate without even knowing each other : This is the human animal in action !
#Text=Fear is illogical and often dumb
#Text=Very often my patients with phobias start with : “ I know it is stupid , but I am afraid of spiders . ”
#Text=Or it may be dogs or cats , or something else .
#Text=And I always reply : “ It is not stupid , it is illogical . ”
#Text=We humans have different functions in the brain , and fear oftentimes bypasses logic .
#Text=There are several reasons .
#Text=One is that logic is slow ; fear is fast .
#Text=In situations of danger , we ought to be fast : First run or kill , then think .
#Text=Some people are afraid of spiders , others of snakes or even cats and dogs .
#Text=Politicians and the media very often use fear to circumvent our logic .
#Text=I always say the U.S. media are disaster pornographers – they work too much on triggering their audiences ’ emotions .
#Text=They are kind of political reality shows , surprising to many from outside the U.S.
#Text=When one person kills a few others in a city of millions , which is of course a tragedy , major networks ’ coverage could lead one to perceive the whole city is under siege and unsafe .

#Text=If one undocumented illegal immigrant murders a U.S. citizen , some politicians use fear with the hope that few will ask : “ This is terrible , but how many people were murdered in this country by U.S. citizens just today ? ”
#Text=Or : “ I know several murders happen every week in this town , but why am I so scared now that this one is being showcased by the media ? ”
#Text=We do not ask these questions , because fear bypasses logic .
#Text=Fear can turn violent
#Text=There is a reason that the response to fear is called the “ fight or flight ” response .
#Text=That response has helped us survive the predators and other tribes that have wanted to kill us .

#Text=But again , it is another loophole in our biology to be abused to turn on our aggression toward “ the others , ” whether in the form of vandalizing their temples or harassing them on the social media .
#Text=“ Desecrated Graves in the Old Jewish Section of the Cemetery , Vienna ” by Scott Rettberg is licensed under CC BY 2.0

#Text=When ideologies manage to get hold of our fear circuitry , we often regress to illogical , tribal and aggressive human animals , becoming weapons ourselves – weapons that politicians use for their own agenda .
#Text=Arash Javanbakht is Assistant Professor of Psychiatry , Wayne State University .
#Text=This essay originally appeared in The Conversation .
#Text=The Politics of Fear : How It Manipulates Us to Tribalism by Arash Javanbakht is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution - NonCommercial 3.0 International License .
